B. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Major County Plant has had no RMP-regulated substance release during the past five years. 

C. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The plant maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.

Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate. Thunderbird has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police, Sheriff's Office, or similar). This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition, Thunderbird conducts periodic emergency drills and annual refresher training for plant personnel.

ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES

Thunderbird Midstream, LLC (Thunderbird) owns and operates a natural gas processing facility, the Major County Plant in Major County, Oklahoma. The plant is designed to process natural gas and recover liquid product from natural gas by physical separation and cryogenic means. Petroleum condensates are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas in this process for off-site sales.

Thunderbird has commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Major County Plant is located near Ames, Oklahoma and operates a variety of processes to produce the following petroleum products: 

1. Residue Gas
2. Natural Gas Liquids
3. Natural Gas Condensate

These substances can contain the following components:

a. Methane
b. Ethane
c. Propane
d. Butane
e. Isobutane
f. Pentane
g. Isopentane

GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

A. WORST CASE SCENARIOS

The worst case scenario associated with a release of flammable substance in Program Level 1 processes at the Major County Plant is a Vapor Cloud Explosion involving the inventory of the largest natural gas liquid (NGL) surge tank containing 13,000 gallons (54,715 lbs) and propane storage tank containing 3,280 gallons (13,863 lbs).
